author: potuz
content: I don't think blind vs unblind makes any difference here. The auction will naturally be sealed in the sense that builders can't trust any bid they see, and at the same time proposers can always just unblind whatever bid they receive

author: potuz
content: so blinding them on protocol is useless

author: 0xai
content: The sealed bid here have a different meaning. Unlike the current open bid auction where other bidders can see the bids, in a sealed bid, other bidders don't have visibility to your bid as a builder. Proposer here is the seller (auctioneer from in-protocol scheme POV).

author: potuz
content: that's what I meant as well

author: terencechain
content: How would second price auctions work here? Note that the proposer selects the bid, not the protocol. The protocol has no visibility of the bids other than the one the proposer selects.

author: 0xai
content: Both theoretically and empirically, open and sealed bids have different effects on the total number of bids, revenues and their distributions.

author: 0xai
content: I haven't given much thought on how exactly it can happen, but assuming proposer has a way to track and select the highest bid as the winner. Then highest bidder wins but pays the second highest price as payment rule.

author: 0xai
content: But I am not exactly sure how they will play out in our in or out protocol PBS scheme. But they will lead to different distributions of payments and different levels of participation.

author: potuz
content: What I am saying is that regardless of wether we force the bid to be sealed, the proposer can unseal it if they want to run an unsealed bid auction. And if we don't want to seal it on protocol, anyway from the point of view of the builder the bid is sealed cause they cannot trust **any** bid they see

author: potuz
content: This is not implementable in protocol, however, open bid auctions naturally tend to this anyway

author: soispoke
content:
we discussed this a bit with RIG, and I think the literature seems to indicate that open bid auctions are usually better at eliciting higher bids (more efficient auction) than sealed bid auctions

But the literature doesn't usually consider sophisticated/strategic participants, which is definitely the case in our setting (builders)

author: 0xai
content: When you say Proposer can unseal it, do you mean proposer can unseal the bids for everyone to see or just herself? If it is the first one, it is a situation similar to bid leakage in the sealed bid auctions. If it is the later, the that is perfectly fine within the definition of sealed bid auction because proposer is the seller of the block rights.

author: potuz

author: potuz
